items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action to Nominate 2010 Outstanding Legislator of the Year and Adoption of Resolution #2009/2010-49 The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is accepting nominations for the 2010 Outstanding Legislator of the Year. Each year, CSBA honors two (2) to four (4) current members of the State Senate and Assembly who work actively to improve our public schools who exercise leadership in the legislative arena. Nominations for the 2010 CSBA Outstanding Legislator of the Year must be submitted to the California School Boards Association and postmarked, faxed or completed online no later than August 27, 2010. The final selection of honorees will be made in September 2010. The awards will be presented at the 2010 CSBA Annual Education Conference in December 2010. FISCAL IMPACT:Not ApplicableFUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees nominate a Senator and/or Assembly Member for CSBA's 2010 Outstanding Legislator of the Year and also adopt Resolution #2009/2010-49 Nomination(s) for 2010 Outstanding Legislator of the Year to the California School Board Association (CSBA)East Side Union High School District of Santa Clara County, State of California RESOLUTION #2009/2010-49Nomination(s) for 2010 Outstanding Legislator of the Year to the California School Boards Association (CSBA)WHEREAS, ______________________demonstrates significant commitment and legislative contributions to public education; WHEREAS, _____________________demonstrates legislative leadership on behalf of public education; WHEREAS, _____________________recognizes and supports local governance for schools;WHEREAS, _____________________ supports key K-12 legislative proposals; WHEREAS, ____________________supports and espouses CSBA’s Legislative Platform;WHEREAS, _____________________ recognizes the significance of CSBA’s role in public education; WHEREAS, _____________________ is active on local school issues and visits K-12 schools regularly;WHEREAS, ___________________is a member of the California State Legislature at the time of nomination;WHEREAS, _____________________ represents the East Side Union High School District. THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, by the East Side Union High School District that _________________ be nominated as CSBA’s 2010 Legislator of the Year.PASSED AND ADOPTED this 20th day of May 2010 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California. AYES: 	________NOES: 	________ABSENT:	________ABSTENTIONS: 	________I certify that the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on May 20th, 2010.  ___________________________________________ Patricia Martinez-Roach, ClerkESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action Regarding Race to the Top Phase 2 MOUThe Race to the Top (RTTT) Phase 2 Memorandum of Understanding is scheduled to be released on Monday, May 17, 2010 to all local education agencies for their consideration and/or action.  Signed RTTT MOUs are required to be submitted to the State no later than May 21, 2010 in order to become a part of the State RTTT Phase 2 application due June 1, 2010.The State's strategy for round two of RTTT is to have six “lead” districts, in collaboration with the Gates Foundation, develop the application for California.   Different this round is that LEAs agreeing to become a part of the grant application cannot be released from the conditions of the MOU.   Local school boards and bargaining associations are encouraged to sign off similar to the original RTTT last January.  Details of the MOU will be shared as they become available.FISCAL IMPACT:To Be DeterminedFUNDING SOURCE:RTTT GrantRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees take action that is appropriate and consistent to the goals of the district in considering the Race to the Top Phase 2 Memorandum of Understanding.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Mary Stone, The Nascent Group, and Kirsten King, Interim Director of Instructional ServicesSUBJECT:Program Improvement Report of Findings PresentationDESCRIPTION: East Side Union High School District became Program Improvement, Year 1, in 2004-05. When the district became PI Year 2 (2005-06), they contracted with the Santa Clara County Office of Education as a provider. In 2006-07 the district selected The Nascent Group as their DAIT provider and has worked with Nascent from 2006 to 2010. During the past four years East Side developed, implemented, and monitored the LEA Addendum and Action Plan that addresses the needs of program improvement areas. Because a formal Report of Findings involving all stakeholders, using the four DAIT tools, (District Assistance Survey examining seven district areas and 39 standards was never administered) had not been done in the past, a full report to assess progress on implementation of the LEA Addendum Plan was scheduled. This report includes an extended needs assessment using the four recently revised (2009) DAIT tools, a set of findings, and recommendations which will be presented to the Board of Education on May 20. The recommendations are used to update the LEA Addendum and Action Plan. This report and update will go to the California Department of Education at the end of May.The following documents are attached:1.	The Report Of Findings2.	PI Recommendations3.	ESUHSD APS Summary4.	PI DAS Standards5.	The ELSSA –  English Learner Subgroup Self Assessment6.	The ISS - Inventory of Services and Supports (ISS) for Students with DisabilitiesFISCAL IMPACT:             NA  FUNDING SOURCE:         NA RECOMMENDATION:     It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the above report.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction and Nick Leon, Rotary MemberSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action Regarding Participation in the Bay AreaCollaborative Social Research Application, a not-for-profit social research organization in Los Altos, CA has submitted a letter of intent as the lead applicant of the Bay Area Collaborative to build a strong linkage support system between the County Department of Health, local high school districts, and community based organizations.  Through the collaborative, the grant proposes to reduce repeat-pregnancies and target at-risk behaviors that lead teens to drop out of school.  The project intends to keep students in school leading to graduation.  The program will also include health education, mentoring services, service learning, and support for teen parent(s).Collaborating partners include:  Sociometrics, Santa Clara AFLP Program, Santa Clara Department of Health, East Side Union High School District, PAB consisting of the Rotary Club San Jose East/Evergreen, Parent Project Santa Clara County District Attorney’s Office, Next Door Solutions, Santa Cruz AFLP, Santa Cruz Health Services Agency, Gilroy High School District, Pajaro Valley Unified School District, and Planned Parenthood Mar Monte.FISCAL IMPACTTBAFUNDING SOURCE:Federal Department of Health GrantRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the district’s participation in the Bay Area Collaborative.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Cari Vaeth, Director of Adult Education and Career ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Grant Application for Carl D. Perkins IV Tech Prep Demonstration Site Grant for Yerba Buena High SchoolOverview:This grant is submitted by the Santa Clara County Construction Careers Association, a consortium of education and industry partners on behalf of the Construction Technology Academy at Yerba Buena High School.  The Construction Technology Academy is organized into sequenced academic and Career Technical Education courses that begin in grade 10 and that culminate with enrollment in an apprenticeship program or enrollment in college or technical school or employment in the related field.  The grant request of $100,000 will be used to provide professional development for teachers, expand recruitment, develop marketing materials and strengthen the student transition process to post secondary education.Accomplishments:Working with S4CA the Construction Technology Academy has implemented worksite learning experiences that include paid summer internships, job placement and industry job site visits.  Exemplary business and industry support includes the Santa Clara Valley Contractors Association, HMH Engineering, American Institute of Architects of Santa Clara Valley, Construction Employers Association, National Labor College and the Silicon Valley Workforce Investment Network. FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Carl D. Perkins IV Tech Prep Demonstration Site Grant ($100,000.00)RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins IV Tech Prep Demonstration Site Grant for Yerba Buena High School.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Accept Third Financial Statement of Projections as required by Education Code Section 42131,eCalifornia Education Code Section 42131,e; requires any school district that files a qualified or negative Second Interim Financial Report to prepare for the County Superintendent, Superintendent of Public Instruction and the State Controller a third financial statement projections of the district’s fund and cash balances.  We are using a summary form of the Interim Financial Report for this purpose.  It is not a requirement of the education code for the Board of Education to declare the financial condition that this report reflects, however, it is important that it be reviewed at a regular scheduled Board meeting.  The economic condition this district is in as represented by this report is unprecedented in this District’s history as is the State of California economy.      FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and accept the report as presented.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services, Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal CounselSUBJECT:Adopt Resolution #2009/2010-46 Approving Energy Services Contract and Authorizing Lease Purchase Agreement for the Purpose of Financing a Portion of the Solar Renewable Energy Project, Designating the Master Equipment Lease Purchase Agreement as a Tax Exempt Obligation; and Authorizing and Prescribing Other Matters Related TheretoSelection Process At the October 2009 Board Meeting the Board of Trustees approved Phase I Solar Photovoltaic Installation project to take place at Andrew Hill High School, Evergreen Valley High School, Foothill High School, Independence High School Santa Teresa High School, and W. C. Overfelt High School.  The project was Board awarded to Chevron.Prior to Phase I the District performed a contractor selection process that resulted in a recommendation that was presented and ultimately approved by the Board in October 2009; even though the Education Code 4217 does allow for districts to waive the solicitation process.  This technology has not changed significantly therefore, it is not warranted that the District spend additional resources to do another extensive solicitation process that would most like result in the same conclusion as we are recommending here.  There would be other things that would need to be heavily considered in our evaluation of other solutions that may be available in the market today.  The primarily consideration is that along with the six sites receiving a district-wide solar technology, educational curriculum was implemented for all high schools related to the installations.  This in itself would warrant a single source justification.  Other considerations are: (1) the continued installation suggests that the same or similar methodology that we just installed remains consistent in appearance and functionality of the solar panels; (2) the maintenance of the solar panels would need to be the same or similar so that maintenance can maintain the equipment on a consistent bases; (3) we would want the same or better savings with the same or better guarantee as Chevron has provided the District.Performance EvaluationOn February 1, 2010 Chevron began the installation of the Solar Photovoltaic Installation with the steel fabrication starting with Evergreen High School and completing with Independence High School.  The project was expected to be completed by June 30, 2010.Their performance during the installation was conducted in a professional and informative manner with extreme consideration of site students and staff.  As issues came up that may have affected the project in a negative way, Chevron’s Project Team kept the District informed at all times.  Most importantly they were able to handle these issues quickly and with minimal affect on the overall project.FISCAL IMPACT:$10,000,000FUNDING SOURCE:School Facilities Fund 35RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the continuance of the contract with Chevron for the purchase and installation of solar photovoltaic at James Lick High School, Mt. Pleasant High School, Oak Grove High School, Piedmont Hills High School, Silver Creek High School, and Yerba Buena High School, Independence Adult Education Center and Adopt Resolution #2009/2010-46 authorizing a lease agreement for the purpose of financing the Chevron Energy Solutions Company project.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Updated Five-Year Deferred Maintenance PlanThe attached updated Five-Year Deferred maintenance Plan was developed with input from principals in charge of facilities over the past year.  The plan describes the Districts needs from a broad perspective for the year 2009 through 2010.  Furthermore, this document addresses campus planning goals and development programs, which will serve to strengthen the campus's physical character, and in turn, support the quality of the educational program.In order for the District to qualify for state matching funds, an updated Deferred Maintenance Plan approved by the Board of Trustees must be submitted to the Office of Public School Construction (OPSC) for the review and approval by the State Allocation board.  As the Board of Trustees is aware, the Five-Year Plan contains needs far in excess of funds available to make all of the necessary repairs and improvement identified.  In addition, this plan does not purport to be an exhaustive listing of all maintenance needs in the District.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:Deferred MaintenanceRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attached updated Five-Year Deferred Maintenance Plan and authorize staff to submit said plan to the Office of Public School Construction for review and approval.

The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting.”   While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the "transparency” of District business.   The legal authorization for an expense comes prior to the issuance of the warrants when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.FISCAL IMPACT:Not ApplicableFUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register for the Month of April 2010.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services, Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and PlanningSUBJECT:Approve Purchase of Twelve Relocatable Classrooms from Williams Scotsman for Evergreen Valley High SchoolOn July 07, 2004, the Board of Trustees approved Lease Agreements between the District and Williams Scotsman to lease a total of twelve relocatable classrooms at Evergreen Valley High School for a duration of 36 months.  A lease extension was then approved by the Board of Trustees on November 11, 2007, for an additional 36 months. All twelve portables have been occupied and will be utilized as classrooms in the foreseeable future.  The administration believes that it would be more cost effective to purchase the relocatable classrooms instead of continued leasing at the current rate of sixty-six thousand dollars a year.  FISCAL IMPACT:                              $279,990.00FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities (Developer Fees) RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of twelve relocatable classrooms instead of continuing to lease them.

BertrandJuly 1, 2010 through and including June 30, 2013$33,700 per year to be paid in 6 semi-annual payments		$18,000 per year to be paid in 6 semi-annual paymentsGeneral FundJerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent Administration and Business ServicesEast Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into an Agreement for Consultant Services with School Innovations & Advocacy for the Mandate Reimbursement Process Program.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.Contractor will provide consulting services to assist the District in the preparation and filing of reimbursement and estimated claims for the costs of the Mandate Reimbursement Process Program, legislatively mandated by the State of California.  The services include: Prepare and file 2009/10, 2010/11 & 2012/13 reimbursement claims;Hold training sessions for District Staff;Monitor district’s mandated cost tracking systems for each Agreement Year;Research and assist District with data collection for test claims approved by the Commission;Serve as a liaison with the State Controller’s Office and Commission; andProvide representation of District with respect to any State audit of claims prepared by consultant.Addendum #1 to the above agreement is issued to amend the contract to include the development of a site service plan for each site as listed and to provide District with the following additional services as follows:Two on-site visits for training and advisory sessions at each designated site each agreement year;Coordinate between District and designated sites for data collections;Advise and assist each site and its personnel as to the requirements and what is needed;Expanded training sessions to included sites;Included milestones to be achieved by each site.Selection Process No solicitation process was completed for this project. RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Approve an Agreement and Addendum #1 with School Innovations & Advocacy, for the Term July 1, 2010 through and including June 30, 2013 for the Provision of consulting services related to the Districts preparation and filing of reimbursement and estimated claims for the costs of the Mandate Reimbursement Process Program, legislatively mandated by the State of California.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and Planning SUBJECT:Approve Measure E Bond Program Status Review and Consideration of Master BudgetThe voters in the East Side Union High School District approved the Measure E General Obligation Bond in February, 2008. The first funds for Measure E were sold in May of 2008. The Board of Trustees approved an initial Measure E Bond Program Budget in February, 2009. Modifications to project scope and attendant budgets have been brought to the Board for consideration and approval in the ensuing period - including April 2009, June 2009, and October 2009.  A combination of these periodic adjustments and economic conditions have had an impact on the internal consistency of the overall Master Measure E Program Budget.Expansion of scope on the Mt. Pleasant Multi-purpose Building to include previously “on-deck” remodeling of classroom quads has enabled the District to leverage bond funds to qualify for $10 million in State Matching funds.  Aggressive schedule management has also enabled concurrent launch of over 30 projects, allowing the District to take full advantage of the exceptional bidding climate and create as many new jobs as possible in the regional market.  A status review of current projects will accompany consideration of this item.It is proposed that a Measure E Master Budget be periodically reconsidered as a means of sustaining an aggressive approach to the delivery of projects under the Measure E bond program, allowing the District to leverage Bond dollars to the maximum extent, while exercising best fiscal practices.The Facilities Bond Team will be present to answer questions from the Board of Trustees.FISCAL IMPACT:   $0 Million FUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed  Measure  E Bond Program Master Budget by Site, limited to Board Approved Scope.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education StudentsDESCRIPTION: DESCRIPTION:  Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:1)	An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.2)	Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.3)	An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students’ parents.The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code Section 60851: Student A items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Approve New CoursesThe Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed the Environmental Science, Aerospace Engineering and Digital Electronics, Introduction to Engineering and Design and Principles of Engineering courses.  These courses were piloted during the 2009 - 2010 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.  Environmental Science: Within the chemistry theme students will learn that subatomic particles are arranged in specific patters to form specific elements. And, the formed elements will react to produce molecules and compounds which are found in nature. Moreover, students will learn how pH, solutions, and polymers apply to the real world, through laboratory and field work analyses.Aerospace Engineering: The major focus of this course is to expose students to the world of aeronautics, flight, and engineering through the fields of aeronautics, aerospace engineering, and related areas of study. Lessons engage students in engineering design problems related to aerospace information systems, astronautics, rocketry, propulsion, the physics of space science, space life sciences, the biology of space science, principles of aeronautics, structures and materials, and systems engineering. Students work in teams utilizing hands-on activities, projects, and problems and are exposed to various situations faced by aerospace engineers. In addition, students use 3D design software to help design solutions to proposed problems. Students design intelligent vehicles to learn about documenting their project, solving problems, and communicating their solutions to their peers and members of the professional community.Digital Electronics: This course is the study of electronic circuits that are used to process and control digital signals. Digital electronics is the foundation of all modern electronic devices such as cellular phones, MP3 players, laptop computers, digital cameras, and high-definition televisions. The major focus of the DE course is to expose students to the design process of combinational and sequential logic design, teamwork communication methods, engineering standards, and technical documentation.Introduction to Engineering and Design: In this course, students use 3D solid modeling design software to help them design solutions to solve proposed problems. Students will learn how to document their work and communicate solutions to peers and members of the professional community. The major focus of the IED course is to expose students to the design process, research and analysis, teamwork, communication methods, global and human impacts, engineering standards, and technical documentation.Principles of Engineering: This survey course of engineering exposes students to some of the major concepts they’ll encounter in a postsecondary engineering course of study. Students have an opportunity to investigate engineering and high-tech careers and to develop skills and understanding of course concepts. Students employ engineering and scientific concepts in the solution of engineering design problems. They develop problem-solving skills and apply their knowledge of research and design to create solutions to various challenges. Students also learn how to document their work and communicate their solutions to peers and members of the professional community.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the courses above.

J. Albanese Inc., as the lowest responsible bidder.    4.  Library and Textbook Management System Bid BidOpeningLegalAdvertisementsAdvertisementDate(s)Project DescriptionRFP-08-09-10April 27, 2010   Daily Post Journal;RFP was available on the District’s WebsiteApril 7, 2010The purchase, installation, training, and maintenance of a library and textbook management system.Bid Results:The District received two responsive and responsible proposals. Another proposal was received 24-hours beyond the due date and was not opened or considered in the evaluation process.The evaluation process consisted of a team of 10 evaluators who represented a broad base of users of the system.  Each evaluator was requested to evaluate the proposer’s responses regarding their ability to meet our minimum product capabilities, pricing and past vendor relations with the District.  The evaluators used a rating scale established by the purchasing department and in conjunction with the requirements described in the Request for Proposals. Purchasing contacted the references and added those scores to the evaluator’s score.  As for the final component in the evaluation, the oral interviews, it was decided by the evaluation committee that enough information had been provided in the written proposals that they did not feel the oral presentations would provide them any additional information that would add to their evaluations.  In consideration of the committee’s recommendation and the need to get the system purchased and implemented as soon as possible, Administration decided to waive the oral presentations and evaluate each of the proposals using a total rating scale of 90% rather than 100%Below are the total scores for each of the proposers:Vendor NameScoringFollett Software Company76%COMPanion Corporation51%FISCAL IMPACT:$155,154 estimated total costs which includes software, maintenance, training, professional development, barcode labels, scanning equipment, and implementation cost thru 1st two years of operation.FUNDING SOURCE:Various categorical fundsRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended to the Board of Trustees award the above listed solicitation process to Follett as the lowest responsible bidder.
